thread.title: WSJ City PM: What to Expect from Zuckerberg’s European Grilling, Cambridge Analytica Staff Told Firm Is Liquidating

author: Darren Lazarus
title: WSJ City PM: What to Expect from Zuckerberg’s European Grilling, Cambridge Analytica Staff Told Firm Is Liquidating
text:
0 COMMENTS Good morning from the WSJ City desks in London. WSJ City is the app that delivers concise, smart news on business and finance for mobile. Download for iPhone or Android . Here’s essential reading on today’s developments.
MUST READS FROM WSJ CITY
Top European lawmakers will interrogate Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg over the company’s handling of alleged user-data misuse and election interference on the platform, as the social-network giant seeks to appease officials in a region where the company is regulated strictly. Here’s what to expect at the grilling, which starts in Brussels around 6:30 pm local time, 12:30 pm ET.
Cambridge Analytica, the firm at the heart of Facebook’s data scandal, is liquidating assets and has asked workers to vacate its London office, according to employees. In an hour-long meeting on site, administrators told about 40 employees that the firm was liquidating to pay off creditors after failing to receive any credible buyers, according to one employee attending.
The Bank of England may raise its key interest rate in ‘a few months’ if the UK economy rebounds from a first-quarter slowdown, Governor Mark Carney and other officials said. Speaking to lawmakers, Carney said the central bank continues to expect to raise its key interest rate gradually over coming years, while signs of a rebound in growth may come soon.
Among all the trade fights that President Trump has picked, his hand against China is the strongest. Yet China, incredibly, appears to be winning, argues chief economics commentator Greg Ip. Meanwhile, the US and China are moving closer toward resolving their trade dispute.
Investors are upping the ante on big oil companies over climate change, demanding they take more concrete action to help curb global warming. The issue was set to come into focus at Royal Dutch Shell ’s annual meeting where investors called on the company to go beyond already ambitious plans to curb emissions.
IN THE PAPERS
Trump and McConnell Plot Path to Hold Congress – WSJ
Toyota Warns Hybrid Clampdown Could Hit UK Plants – FT
Jacob Rees-Mogg Hints He’s Losing Faith in UK’s May – Bloomberg
Trump and Moon Meet Amid Rising Doubts on North Korea – Politico
Egypt’s Sisi Clamped Down on Political Opposition, Next Up Is the Economy – WSJ
MARKETS TODAY
European stocks closed higher on waning concerns about trade tension. The Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.4%, while the FTSE 100 ended the session up 0.2%.
The somewhat upbeat tone in markets came after US industrial companies rallied on Monday after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the US would suspend its efforts to apply tariffs to $150 billion in Chinese imports.
Italy’s MIB index bucked recent losses to rise 0.5% on news that the anti-establishment 5 Star Movement and League parties chose Giuseppe Conte as their compromise candidate for prime minister. Italian bonds also recovered in a relief trade, with yields on 10-year government bonds falling around nine basis points.
Brent crude prices again breached the $80 a barrel threshold after Washington threatened ‘the strongest sanctions in history’ if Iran did not yield to US demands.
The Dow and Nasdaq Composite traded close to the flatline.
